data.title: Regex Find can cause VS Code to Freeze
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: Mac OSX Sierra 10.12.5 (16F73)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. `code --disable-extensions`
1. *File->New File*
1. Paste file from here: [snippets.py](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/python-docs-samples/master/auth/http-client/snippets.py) (it happens with other files, but this is a simple example)
1. Edit->Find  `"""(.*?\n?)+?"""` regex
1. Try to remove the last `?` from the regex.
1. The editor freezes at this point
1. Code Helper goes to 100% CPU.

Result:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3740137/28280643-bcdb1b42-6b24-11e7-81af-649bca4f45c9.png)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Toggle comment should support frontmatter in .md files
data.body:
Since we support frontmatter syntax formatting we should support it in toggle comment too.

```markdown
---
a: b
---

# test
```

Toggle comment on the second line gives:

```markdown
---
<!-- a: b -->
---

# test
```

Expected:

```markdown
---
# a: b
---

# test
```

---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
tslint|eg2|0.16.0
typescript-javascript-grammar|ms-|0.0.23



---

Steps to Reproduce:

```
"editor.formatOnType": false,
"editor.autoIndent": false
```

1. Change lang mode to JavaScript.
2. Insert into editor:
```js
var x = {

};
```
3. Ensure there is no whitespace in the empty line from the code in step 2.
4. Create a newline from the empty line (`enter`/`ctrl+enter`)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

The expected result, at least historically, is that the new line doesn't auto indent.

data.title: Save Workspace As: use new ID when workspace already saved?
data.body: We should decide if saving an already saved workspace should put a new unique ID into the workspace configuration file or keep the same. The downside of using the same ID is that you suddenly end up having state spread across multiple locations (path of the config file for settings and the ID for the rest).

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 x64

Bundled node.js v7.4.0 is being flagged up as insecure as it contains an older version of OpenSSL

Further info: https://nodejs.org/en/blog/vulnerability/july-2017-security-releases/

data.title: vscode.startDebug with type "node" vs. "node2"
data.body:
"vscode.startDebug" does not respect `type: "node2"` when the configuration supplies `type: "node"`, as it happens in the embedded extension for node.js debugging.

## Background

Visual Studio Code tracing shows that the embedded extension for node.js debugging actually uses `type: "node2"`, even when the auto-generated file "launch.json" provides `type: "node"`. Moreover, `type: "node"` if supplied to the "complex command" "vscode.startDebug" does not work anymore (see steps to reproduce below).

This is very confusing and not documented. The cases of "node2" and "node" should be merged to eliminate "node2". In worst case, this peculiarity should be thoroughly documented.

Related to [24762](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/24762).

## Steps to Reproduce:

### 0) Use node.js 8.1.4

### 1) Try node.js debugging with "launch.json":

```
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Launch Extension",
            "type": "extensionHost",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${file}",
            "protocol": "auto" // anything but "legacy"
            ],
        }
    ]
}
```
It does work.

### 2) Now, in some extension code:

```
        const launchConfiguration = {
            type: "node", // a real confusion! found by tracing Visual Studio Code
            name: "Launch Extension",
            request: "launch",
            stopOnEntry: false,
            protocol: "auto"
        };
        vscode.commands.executeCommand("vscode.startDebug", launchConfiguration);
```
It shows the error:
> [DEP0062] DeprecationWarning: `node --debug` and `node --debug-brk` are invalid. Please use `node --inspect` or `node --inspect-brk` instead

### 3) The workaround:

Change `type: "node"` to `type: "node2"`. It works.

## 
Reproduces without extensions: No (the problem appears in extension, more exactly)

data.title: Changed/Deleted workspace should turn into untitled workspace

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I think we need to listen to changes to the workspace config file and migrate a window into "Untitled Workspace" once:

* the underlying config file gets deleted or renamed or moved to a different location

Looks like the a similar transition that we now have for Untitled => Workspace needs to be supported the other way around as well.

data.title: MRU list for workspaces does not show the recently opened workspace
data.body:
- Open a empty workspace
- `Add Folders to Workspace...` (select a single folder)
- It opens the workspace
- Now `Open Folder...` from the workspace
- Select a folder
- A prompt comes to Save Workspace
- Save it as `a.vscode-workspace`
- It opens Folder you selected before
- See the MRU.. Observe that `a.vscode-workspace` is not there in the list

Autoindent: Wrong automatic indent for JavaScript after indented "if"
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14
- OS Version: 10.12.5

![vsc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50314/28269787-8c5de70e-6b03-11e7-96d1-0584f5ec7dad.gif)

Steps to Reproduce:

* Type this:

```javascript
if (true ||
  false) {
```

* Hit Enter.
* Automatically inserted brace are intended wrong and the cursor ends up at the wrong indentation level:

```javascript
if (true ||
  false) {
    <caret>
}
```

The indent must follow the `if`, not the indented second line of the condition expression.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Autoindent: Space doesn't indent certain lines
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

* Set `editor.autoIndent` to true.
* Start with this code:

```JavaScript
if (true ||
 ) {
```

* Place cursor on the second line, before the `)`.
* Hit Space.
* Nothing happens.

Further bugginess:

* Move the caret to _after_ the `)`.
* Hit Space.
* Line will be unindented. In fact, this will generally happen if you enter anything on that line.

![vsc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50314/28269653-1a48cc38-6b03-11e7-9c01-79928bf0e963.gif)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: autoGuessEncoding improvements
data.body:
At the moment, Code is not very good with automatic guessing the encoding, and work on projects with non-utf8 encodings.
There are 2 proposals that could improve the current situation:

1. Cache the previously selected encodings for files in the format `{ filepath: encoding }`. You can set a limit on the N most recently opened files, for example. This will give an increase in performance when opening recent files and will save you from incorrect recognition of the encoding. This feature can be implemented in the context of the project, workspace or globally.

2. Provide the possibility to specify used encodings in the project settings. Suppose we are working on a project that has legacy codebase in windows1251, and the rest of the files are in utf8. We can specify something like `{ projectEncodings: ['windows1251', 'utf8'] }`, and if the file's encoding is auto-detected, the editor will notify you, that the encoding is most likely not detected correctly. This option is perfectly matched with the first paragraph.

milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:18:47.188Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
pgsql|dou|0.0.8
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
JSDocTagComplete|Hoo|0.0.2
vscode-esformatter|how|1.5.2
output-colorizer|IBM|0.1.2
vscode-puglint|mrm|2.3.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Hover over a variable while debugging. Sometimes the layout is broken and only shows a single data member:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1658949/28268290-fa6a2920-6afd-11e7-8eb6-ef7d6bb00a22.png)

Manually scrolling the scrollbar indicates that there is more content hidden behind the broken layout:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1658949/28268320-261f5f54-6afe-11e7-8674-c59d4237be1d.gif)

This doesn't seem to happen for every variable, but the behavior seems to be consistent for any given variable. So it might be related to the data itself.

When I evaluate the variable in the Debug Console, it is displayed just fine.

data.title: disturbing alert when adding another folder to a workspace
data.body:
[I'm filing this issue as a long time VS Code user, not as a dev who understands what's going on...]
 
When trying to add a new folder to an existing workspace, I get the following alert:

![2017-07-17_14-23-45](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/28267867-45022318-6afc-11e7-8003-3f8b003960fe.png)

As a long time VS Code user, I am a bit surprised by the wording because in my current understanding I have already a "workspace" and I cannot really understand why the alert says that I do not have a "workspace".

Could we change the wording so that it sounds less scary, e.g. something like:
"Before we can add another folder we need to upgrade your workspace to support multiple folders..."

data.title: Can't install extensions anymore
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0 insider
- OS Version: Win Srv 2012 64 bit

## Steps to Reproduce:

1. Go the the `Extensions` side bar `CTRL + SHFT + X`
2. Search for an extension, for example `Bimbo Theme`
3. Click the button `Install`

Nothing happens, the text `Install` changes to `Installing` and then gets back to `Install` without anything installed or any notification of what happened.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10828570/28265761-a716bee8-6af1-11e7-8e9e-7d7e796f5f7c.png)

This is for all extensions the case, not just this theme.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Better support "Save Workspace" when in single folder workspace context
data.body:
In Single Folder Context, requesting to Save Workspace currently 

- Asks to create a new workspace with existing folder
- Create a New Workspace 
- Asks to add more folders to the Workspace
- Then opens newly create workspace
- Then user has to trigger Save Workspace action again. 

This is not helping user at all. Instead, requesting to Save Workspace in Single Folder context should

- Ask to create a new workspace with existing folder and **Save**
- Asks for the location to Save the newly created workspace
- Open the newly saved workspace

data.title: High CPU usage when opening certain folders
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: 10.12.5

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

## Steps to Reproduce:
1. `$ cd ~` (not sure you are able to reproduce in yours)
2. `$ code .`

**CPU goes sky high**
```
% CPU
167.8 12.1  5206772 2029252   ??  RN   11:20am   6:48.62 /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Frameworks/Code Helper.app/Contents/MacOS/Code Helper /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/bootstrap --type=watcherService

101.2  7.5  4795848 1255188   ??  R    11:20am   5:42.60 /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Frameworks/Code Helper.app/Contents/MacOS/Code Helper /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/bootstrap --type=searchService
```

When I close the window, I notice one of processes remain alive:
```
% CPU
102.0  7.5  4804052 1255220   ??  R    11:20am   8:38.15 /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Frameworks/Code Helper.app/Contents/MacOS/Code Helper /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/bootstrap --type=searchService
```

After killing the remaining process, `find` kicks in:
```
% CPU
100.0  0.0  2497332   4280   ??  R    11:20am   1:06.23 find -L . -not ( ( -name node_modules -o -name .git -o -name .svn -o -name .hg -o -name CVS -o -name .DS_Store ) -prune ) -type f
```
**Note:** Up until this point, this process was there but not consuming CPU at all.

Usually `find` goes away by itself.

data.title: Path issues with -i

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
@idan says

> @joaomoreno, so happy to have run across this issue after tearing all my hair out trying to understand why my extensions had a path of `/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin`. I'm on OSX, fish 2.5.0., 1.14.0.
>
> Getting the same behavior as @lunaryorn above — removing the `-i` or changing the spawn's stdio to `['pipe', 'pipe', process.stderr]` results in returned output containing the correct `PATH`. If I dig into `result.envPairs` it's still `PATH=/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin` though, I don't grok what's going on there.
>
> This is causing the [vscode flow extension](https://github.com/flowtype/flow-for-vscode) to blow up, claiming that node isn't in the PATH, because node isn't installed in any one of `/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin`.
>
> I tried the insiders build you linked in your last comment here, but it doesn't seem to solve anything. Any pointers on how I can try running a build with the changes from #29864? Do I just need to figure out how to build VSCode? Are there any shortcuts there?
> 
> Thanks for all of your hard work on this — it's really appreciated! ✨ 🍰
